The English is slightly over-specific here: it entails that both goings-to-the-market were in the past, which may or may not be true in the Lojban sentence, since the implied interval is vague. Therefore, the interval may start in the past but extend into the present or even the future.

quantified temporal tensenegating with "nai"
Adding -nai to roi is also permitted, and has the meaning other than (the number specified) :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu reroinai citka le cirla
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The rat eats the cheese other than twice.

section.para: This may mean that the rat eats the cheese fewer times, or more times, or not at all.

whole time intervalexpressing
quantified temporal tenses"once" contrasted with "only once"
quantified temporal tensescaveat on implication of
It is necessary to be careful with sentences like
and
, where a quantified tense appears without an interval. What
really says is that during an interval of unspecified size, at least part of which was set in the past, the event of my going to the market happened twice. The example says nothing about what happened outside that vague time interval. This is often less than we mean. If we want to nail down that I went to the market once and only once, we can use the cmavo ze'e which represents the whole time interval : conceptually, an interval which stretches from time's beginning to its end:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ze'e paroi klama le zarci

section.para:
Since specifying no ZEhA leaves the interval vague,
might in appropriate context mean the same as
after all – but
allows us to be specific when specificity is necessary.

PU selma'owith "ze'e"
ze'ecameaning of
ze'ebameaning of
ze'epumeaning of
ze'eeffect on following PU direction
temporal directionexception in meaning when following "ze'e"
A PU cmavo following ze'e has a slightly different meaning from one that follows another ZEhA cmavo. The compound cmavo ze'epu signifies the interval stretching from the infinite past to the reference point (wherever the imaginary journey has taken you); ze'eba is the interval stretching from the reference point to the infinite future. The remaining form, ze'eca , makes specific the whole of time interpretation just given. These compound forms make it possible to assert that something has never happened without asserting that it never will.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ze'epu noroi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I have never gone to the market.

section.para: says nothing about whether I might go in future.

quantified space The space equivalent of ze'e is ve'e , and it can be used in the same way with a quantified space tense: see
for an explanation of space interval modifiers.

section.title: Event contours: ZAhO and re'u
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

aspectnatural languages compared with respect to
aspectexpressing
resumptive event contour pausative event contour achievative event contour superfective event contour completitive event contour cessitive event contour initiative event contour retrospective event contour continuitive event contour inchoative event contour The cmavo of selma'o ZAhO express the Lojban version of what is traditionally called aspect. This is not a notion well expressed by English tenses, but many languages (including Chinese and Russian among Lojban's six source languages) consider it more important than the specification of mere position in time.

event contoursorder with respect to TAhE and ROI
event contourssyntax of
eventsconsidered as a process
event contoursdefinition
The event contours of selma'o ZAhO, with their bizarre keywords, represent the natural portions of an event considered as a process, an occurrence with an internal structure including a beginning, a middle, and an end. Since the keywords are scarcely self-explanatory, each ZAhO will be explained in detail here. Note that from the viewpoint of Lojban syntax, ZAhOs are interval modifiers like TAhEs or ROI compounds; if both are found in a single tense, the TAhE/ROI comes first and the ZAhO afterward. The imaginary journey described by other tense cmavo moves us to the portion of the event-as-process which the ZAhO specifies.

event contoursas characteristic portions of events
speaker-relative viewpointcontrasted with event-relative viewpoint
event-relative viewpointcontrasted with speaker-relative viewpoint
tensesviewpoint of PU contrasted with viewpoint of ZAhO
PU selma'oPU tenses contrasted with ZAhO tenses in viewpoint
event contoursas timeless in perspective
It is important to understand that ZAhO cmavo, unlike the other tense cmavo, specify characteristic portions of the event, and are seen from an essentially timeless perspective. The beginning of an event is the same whether the event is in the speaker's present, past, or future. It is especially important not to confuse the speaker-relative viewpoint of the PU tenses with the event-relative viewpoint of the ZAhO tenses.

ca'oderivation of word
ba'oderivation of word
pu'oderivation of word
The cmavo pu'o , ca'o , and ba'o (etymologically derived from the PU cmavo) refer to an event that has not yet begun, that is in progress, or that has ended, respectively:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I'm on the verge of fighting.
Steve continues to talk.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba ba'o cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The child is no longer walking on the ice.

section.para:
tense directioncontrasted with event contours in implication of extent
event contourscontrasted with tense direction in implication of extent
event contoursimplications on scope of event
event contoursretrospective
event contourscontinuitive
event contoursinchoative
As discussed in
, the simple PU cmavo make no assumptions about whether the scope of a past, present, or future event extends into one of the other tenses as well.
through
illustrate that these ZAhO cmavo do make such assumptions possible: the event in
has not yet begun, definitively; likewise, the event in
is definitely over.

ba'oas futureward of event
pu'oas pastward of event
ba'oexplanation of derivation
pu'oexplanation of derivation
Note that in
and
, pu'o and ba'o may appear to be reversed: pu'o , although etymologically connected with pu , is referring to a future event; whereas ba'o , connected with ba , is referring to a past event. This is the natural result of the event-centered view of ZAhO cmavo. The prospective, or pu'o , part of an event, is in the pastward portion of that event, when seen from the perspective of the event itself. It is only by inference that we suppose that
refers to the speaker's future: in fact, no PU tense is given, so the prospective part of the event need not be coincident with the speaker's present: pu'o is not necessarily, though in fact often is, the same as ca pu'o.

event contourscessative
event contoursinitiative
event contoursdivision of the event into
event contourspoints associated with
The cmavo in
through
refer to spans of time. There are also two points of time that can be usefully associated with an event: the beginning, marked by co'a , and the end, marked by co'u. Specifically, co'a marks the boundary between the pu'o and ca'o parts of an event, and co'u marks the boundary between the ca'o and ba'o parts:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba co'a citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I will begin to eat my meal.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu co'u citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I ceased eating my meal.

section.para:
Compare
with:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I will regularly begin to run.

section.para: which illustrates the combination of a TAhE with a ZAhO.

event contourscompletitive
stopcontrasted with finish
finishcontrasted with stop
actual stopcontrasted with natural end
natural endcontrasted with actual stop
A process can have two end points, one reflecting the natural end (when the process is complete) and the other reflecting the actual stopping point (whether complete or not).
may be contrasted with:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu mo'u citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I finished eating my meal.

section.para:
In
, the meal has reached its natural end; in
, the meal has merely ceased, without necessarily reaching its natural end.

event contoursresumptive
event contourspausative
event contoursresumption
event contoursinterruption
begincontrasted with resume
resumecontrasted with begin
pausecontrasted with stop
stopcontrasted with pause
A process such as eating a meal does not necessarily proceed uninterrupted. If it is interrupted, there are two more relevant point events: the point just before the interruption, marked by de'a , and the point just after the interruption, marked by di'a. Some examples:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu de'a citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I stopped eating my meal (with the intention of resuming).

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba di'a citka le mi sanmi
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I will resume eating my meal.

section.para:
event contourssuperfective
natural endcontinuing beyond
In addition, it is possible for a process to continue beyond its natural end. The span of time between the natural and the actual end points is represented by za'o :

interlinear-gloss.natlang: The teacher kept on explaining the mathematics problem to the class too long.

section.para: That is, the teacher went on explaining after the class already understood the problem.

pointevent considered as
event contoursachievative
An entire event can be treated as a single moment using the cmavo co'i :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .djan. pu co'i catra la djim
interlinear-gloss.natlang: John was at the point in time where he killed Jim.

section.para: cycles ordinal tense Finally, since an activity is cyclical, an individual cycle can be referred to using a number followed by re'u , which is the other cmavo of selma'o ROI:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go to the store for the first time (within a vague interval).

section.para: Note the difference between:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pare'u paroi klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.natlang: For the first time, I go to the store once.

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi paroi pare'u klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.natlang: There is one occasion on which I go to the store for the first time.

section.title: Space interval modifiers: FEhE
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

tenseorder of spatial interval modifiers in
spatial interval modifiersorder in tense
spatial intervalsexpressing degree of continuity over
space intervalscompared with time intervals in continuity
Like time intervals, space intervals can also be continuous, discontinuous, or repetitive. Rather than having a whole separate set of selma'o for space interval properties, we instead prefix the flag fe'e to the cmavo used for time interval properties. A space interval property would be placed just after the space interval size and/or dimensionality cmavo:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ko vi'i fe'e di'i sombo le gurni
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Sow the grain in a line and evenly!

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi fe'e ciroi tervecnu lo selsalta
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I buy salad ingredients in three locations.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ze'e roroi ve'e fe'e roroi ku
… li re su'i re du li vo
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Always and everywhere, two plus two is four.

section.para:
As shown in
, when a tense comes first in a bridi, rather than in its normal position before the selbri (in this case du), it is emphasized.

ZAhO selma'ofor expressing spatial contours
spatial contoursexpressing
The fe'e marker can also be used for the same purpose before members of ZAhO. (The cmavo be'a belongs to selma'o FAhA; it is the space direction meaning north of.)

interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is the beginning of a rock extending to my north.
That is the south face of a rock.

section.para:
event contourstemporal contrasted with spatial
spatial contourscontrasted with temporal event contours
beginning pointspatial
Here the notion of a beginning point represented by the cmavo co'a is transferred from beginning in time to beginning in space under the influence of the fe'e flag. Space is not inherently oriented, unlike time, which flows from past to future: therefore, some indication of orientation is necessary, and the ve'abe'a provides an orientation in which the south face is the beginning and the north face is the end , since the rock extends from south (near me) to north (away from me).

FAhA selma'ouse in specifying space/time mapping direction
space/time metaphorexpressing direction mapping for
spaceas time-based metaphor
timeas space-based metaphor
Many natural languages represent time by a space-based metaphor: in English, what is past is said to be behind us. In other languages, the metaphor is reversed. Here, Lojban is representing space (or space interval modifiers) by a time-based metaphor: the choice of a FAhA cmavo following a VEhA cmavo indicates which direction is mapped onto the future. (The choice of future rather than past is arbitrary, but convenient for English-speakers.)

fe'eeffect of TAhE/ROI with ZAhO on
ZAhO selma'oeffect on "fe'e" flag for TAhE and ROI
ROI selma'oeffect of ZAhO on "fe'e" flag
TAhE selma'oeffect of ZAhO on "fe'e" flag
If both a TAhE (or ROI) and a ZAhO are present as space interval modifiers, the fe'e flag must be prefixed to each.

section.title: Tenses as sumtcita
section.para:
argument tagsbased on tenses (see also sumtcita) sumtcitabased on tenses temporal informationadding to a sentence with tense sumtcita
spatial informationadding to a sentence with tense sumtcita
tensesuse as sumtcita
So far, we have seen tenses only just before the selbri, or (equivalently in meaning) floating about the bridi with ku. There is another major use for tenses in Lojban: as sumtcita, or argument tags. A tense may be used to add spatial or temporal information to a bridi as, in effect, an additional place:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci ca le nu do klama
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [present] the event-of you go-to

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go to the market when you go to the house.

section.para:
sumtcitabased on tense direction
tense directionas sumtcita
cameaning as a sumtcita
Here ca does not appear before the selbri, nor with ku ; instead, it governs the following sumti, the le nu construct. What
asserts is that the action of the main bridi is happening at the same time as the event mentioned by that sumti. So ca , which means now when used with a selbri, means simultaneously-with when used with a sumti. Consider another example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci pu le nu do pu klama
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [past] the event-of you [past] go-to

section.para: The second pu is simply the past tense marker for the event of your going to the house, and says that this event is in the speaker's past. How are we to understand the first pu , the sumtcita?

imaginary journeystarting at a different point
imaginary journeystarting point
All of our imaginary journeys so far have started at the speaker's location in space and time. Now we are specifying an imaginary journey that starts at a different location, namely at the event of your going to the house.
then says that my going to the market is in the past, relative not to the speaker's present moment, but instead relative to the moment when you went to the house.
can therefore be translated:

blockquote.para: I had gone to the market before you went to the house.

section.para:
sumtcitabased on tense distance
tense distanceas sumtcita
spatial tensesas sumtcita
(Other translations are possible, depending on the ever-present context.) Spatial direction and distance sumtcita are exactly analogous:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu cu citka le cirla vi le panka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The rat - eats the cheese [short-time-distance] the park.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The rat eats the cheese near the park.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu cu citka le cirla vi le vu panka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The rat - eats the cheese [short-distance] the [long-distance] park
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The rat eats the cheese near the faraway park.

indexterm.primary: far away from the nearby park

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu cu citka le cirla vu le vi panka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The rat - eats the cheese [long-distance] the [short-distance] park
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The rat eats the cheese far away from the nearby park.

section.para:
sumtcita based on event contoursrelation of main bridi to sumti process in
sumtcitaevent contours contrasted with direction/distance as basis for
tense direction/distance as sumtcitacontrasted with event contours
event contours as sumtcitacontrasted with direction and distance
ZAhO selma'o sumtcitabased on spatial contours
spatial contoursas sumtcita
sumtcitabased on event contours
event contoursas sumtcita
The event contours of selma'o ZAhO (and their space equivalents, prefixed with fe'e) are also useful as sumtcita. The interpretation of ZAhO tcita differs from that of FAhA, VA, PU, and ZI tcita, however. The event described in the sumti is viewed as a process, and the action of the main bridi occurs at the phase of the process which the ZAhO specifies, or at least some part of that phase. The action of the main bridi itself is seen as a point event, so that there is no issue about which phase of the main bridi is intended. For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi morsi ba'o le nu mi jmive
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-dead [retrospective] the event-of I live.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I am dead in the aftermath of my living.

section.para:
Here the (point-)event of my being dead is the portion of my living-process which occurs after the process is complete. Contrast
with:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi morsi ba le nu mi jmive
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-dead [future] the event-of I live.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I am dead after my living.

section.para:
As explained in
,
does not exclude the possibility that I died before I ceased to live!
Likewise, we might say:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci pu'o le nu mi citka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the store [prospective] the event-of I eat

section.para: which indicates that before my eating begins, I go to the store, whereas

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci ba'o le nu mi citka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the store [retrospective] the event-of I eat

section.para: would indicate that I go to the store after I am finished eating.
Here is an example which mixes temporal ZAhO (as a tense) and spatial ZAhO (as a sumtcita):

interlinear-gloss.natlang: The boat sailed for too long and beyond the lake.

section.para:
Probably it sailed up onto the dock. One point of clarification: although xelklama appears to mean simply is-a-mode-of-transport , it does not – the bridi of
has four omitted arguments, and thus has the (physical) journey which goes on too long as part of its meaning.

sumtcita based on quantified tenses quantified tensesas sumtcita
sumtcita based on interval properties interval propertiesmeaning as sumtcita
sumtcita based on interval continuousness interval continuousnessmeaning as sumtcita
sumtcita based on dimension dimensionmeaning as sumtcita
sumtcita based on interval size interval sizemeaning as sumtcita
The remaining tense cmavo, which have to do with interval size, dimension, and continuousness (or lack thereof) are interpreted to let the sumti specify the particular interval over which the main bridi operates:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci reroi le ca djedi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [twice] the [present] day.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go/went/will go to the market twice today.

section.para:
tense inside sumticontrasted with tense as sumtcita
tense as sumtcitacontrasted with tense inside sumti
Be careful not to confuse a tense used as a sumtcita with a tense used within a seltcita sumti:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: Snow falls during this winter.

section.para: claims that the interval specified by this winter is long, as events of snowfall go, whereas

interlinear-gloss.jbo: loi snime cu carvi ca le ze'u dunra
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Snow falls in the long winter.

section.para: claims that during some part of the winter, which is long as winters go, snow falls.

section.title: Sticky and multiple tenses: KI
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

imaginary journey originwith sticky tenses
sticky tenseseffect on future tense meaning
sticky tensesdefinition
tensescope of
So far we have only considered tenses in isolated bridi. Lojban provides several ways for a tense to continue in effect over more than a single bridi. This property is known as stickiness : the tense gets stuck and remains in effect until explicitly unstuck. In the metaphor of the imaginary journey, the place and time set by a sticky tense may be thought of as a campsite or way-station: it provides a permanent origin with respect to which other tenses are understood. Later imaginary journeys start from that point rather than from the speaker.
To make a tense sticky, suffix ki to it:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: … .i le nanmu cu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I went to the market. The man bit the dog.

section.para: Here the use of puki rather than just pu ensures that the tense will affect the next sentence as well. Otherwise, since the second sentence is tenseless, there would be no way of determining its tense; the event of the second sentence might happen before, after, or simultaneously with that of the first sentence.

(The last statement does not apply when the two sentences form part of a narrative. See
for an explanation of story time , which employs a different set of conventions.)
What if the second sentence has a tense anyway?

interlinear-gloss.jbo: … .i le nanmu pu batci le gerku

section.para:
Here the second pu does not replace the sticky tense, but adds to it, in the sense that the starting point of its imaginary journey is taken to be the previously set sticky time. So the translation of
is:

example.para: I went to the market. The man had earlier bitten the dog.

section.para:
compound tensecompared with tense in scope of sticky tense
tense in scope of sticky tensecompared with compound tense
and it is equivalent in meaning (when considered in isolation from any other sentences) to:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: … .i le nanmu pupu batci le gerku

section.para:
compound tensecompared with multiple tenses in sentence
tensesmultiple in sentence compared with compound tense
tensesmultiple in sentence
The point has not been discussed so far, but it is perfectly grammatical to have more than one tense construct in a sentence:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: puku mi ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Earlier, I was going to go to the market.

section.para:
Here there are two tenses in the same bridi, the first floating free and specified by puku , the second in the usual place and specified by ba. They are considered cumulative in the same way as the two tenses in separate sentences of .
is therefore equivalent in meaning, except for emphasis, to:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I was going to go to the market.

section.para:
multiple tenseseffect of order in sentence
Compare
and
, which have a different meaning from
and
:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ba klama le zarci puku
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I will have gone to the market earlier.
I will have gone to the market.

section.para: So when multiple tense constructs in a single bridi are involved, order counts – the tenses cannot be shifted around as freely as if there were only one tense to worry about.

sticky tensesfrom part of a multiple tense
But why bother to allow multiple tense constructs at all? They specify separate portions of the imaginary journey, and can be useful in order to make part of a tense sticky. Consider
, which adds a second bridi and a ki to
:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pu ki ku mi ba klama le zarci
… .i le nanmu cu batci le gerku

section.para: What is the implied tense of the second sentence? Not puba , but only pu , since only pu was made sticky with ki. So the translation is:

blockquote.para: I was going to go to the market. The man bit the dog.

section.para:
sumti with tenseeffect of main bridi tense on
embedded bridi tenseseffect of main bridi tense on
tense on main bridieffect on embedded sumti with tenses
tense on main bridieffect on embedded bridi tenses
tenseon embedded bridi
Lojban has several ways of embedding a bridi within another bridi: descriptions, abstractors, relative clauses. (Technically, descriptions contain selbri rather than bridi.) Any of the selbri of these subordinate bridi may have tenses attached. These tenses are interpreted relative to the tense of the main bridi:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu klama le ba'o zarci
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I went to the former market.

section.para:
The significance of the ba'o in
is that the speaker's destination is described as being in the aftermath of being a market ; that is, it is a market no longer. In particular, the time at which it was no longer a market is in the speaker's past, because the ba'o is interpreted relative to the pu tense of the main bridi.
Here is an example involving an abstraction bridi:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ca jinvi le du'u mi ba morsi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I now opine the fact-that I will-be dead.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I now believe that I will be dead.

section.para: Here the event of being dead is said to be in the future with respect to the opinion, which is in the present.

kiwith no tense
sticky tensescanceling
ki may also be used as a tense by itself. This cancels all stickiness and returns the bridi and all following bridi to the speaker's location in both space and time.

tensehandling multiple episodes
tensesubscripting
subscriptsfor sticky tense
In complex descriptions, multiple tenses may be saved and then used by adding a subscript to ki. A time made sticky with kixipa (ki-sub-1) can be returned to by specifying kixipa as a tense by itself. In the case of written expression, the writer's here-and-now is often different from the reader's, and a pair of subscripted ki tenses could be used to distinguish the two.

section.title: Story time
section.para:
storiesflow of time in story timerationale for story timedefinition
Making strict use of the conventions explained in
would be intolerably awkward when a story is being told. The time at which a story is told by the narrator is usually unimportant to the story. What matters is the flow of time within the story itself. The term story in this section refers to any series of statements related in more-or-less time-sequential order, not just a fictional one.

story timetenseless sentences in
tenseless sentences in story time story timeas a convention for inferring tense
Lojban speakers use a different set of conventions, commonly called story time , for inferring tense within a story. It is presumed that the event described by each sentence takes place some time more or less after the previous ones. Therefore, tenseless sentences are implicitly tensed as what happens next. In particular, any sticky time setting is advanced by each sentence.
The following mini-story illustrates the important features of story time. A sentence-by-sentence explication follows:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pu zu ki ku ne'i ki le kevna
… le ninmu goi ko'a zutse le rokci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: … the woman defined-as she-1 sat-on the rock
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Long ago, in a cave, a woman sat on a rock.
She was eating goat's meat.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: .i ko'a pu jukpa ri le mudyfagri
interlinear-gloss.natlang: She had cooked the meat over a wood fire.
The meat was pleasantly warm.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: … ba za ki nenri klama le kevna
interlinear-gloss.natlang: A while later, a wolf came into the cave.
It took the meat from her.
It ran out.

section.para:
story tenseLojban convention contrasted with English convention
sets both the time (long ago) and the place (in a cave) using ki , just like the sentence sequences in . No further space cmavo are used in the rest of the story, so the place is assumed to remain unchanged. The English translation of
is marked for past tense also, as the conventions of English storytelling require: consequently, all other English translation sentences are also in the past tense. (We don't notice how strange this is; even stories about the future are written in past tense!) This conventional use of past tense is not used in Lojban narratives.

has an explicit tense. This is taken relative to the latest setting of the sticky time; therefore, the event of
happens before that of . It cannot be determined if
happens before or after .

is again tenseless. Story time was not changed by the flashback in
, so
happens after .

and
are again tenseless, and so happen after . (Story time is changed.)

So the overall order is
-
-
-
- (medium interval) -
-
- . It is also possible that
happens before .

story timewith no initial sticky time
If no sticky time (or space) is set initially, the story is set at an unspecified time (or space): the effect is like that of choosing an arbitrary reference point and making it sticky. This style is common in stories that are jokes. The same convention may be used if the context specifies the sticky time sufficiently.

section.title: Tenses in subordinate bridi
section.para: subordinate clausestense usage rules in English English has a set of rules, formally known as sequence of tense rules , for determining what tense should be used in a subordinate clause, depending on the tense used in the main sentence. Here are some examples:

example.para: John says that George is going to the market.
John says that George went to the market.
John said that George went to the market.
John said that George had gone to the market.

section.para:
In
and
, the tense of the main sentence is the present: says. If George goes when John speaks, we get the present tense is going ( goes would be unidiomatic); if George goes before John speaks, we get the past tense went. But if the tense of the main sentence is the past, with said , then the tense required in the subordinate clause is different. If George goes when John speaks, we get the past tense went ; if George goes before John speaks, we get the past-perfect tense had gone.

subordinate clause tenseeffect of main bridi tense on
subordinate clause tenseLojban compared with Esperanto
subordinate clause tenseLojban compared with Russian
subordinate clause tenseLojban contrasted with English
sequence of tense rulesLojban contrasted with English
Lojban, like Russian and Esperanto, uses a different convention. A tense in a subordinate bridi is understood to be relative to the tense already set in the main bridi. Thus
through
can be expressed in Lojban respectively thus:

indexterm.primary: John says that George goes to market

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .djan. ca cusku le se du'u
la .djan. ca cusku le se du'u
la .djan. pu cusku le se du'u
la .djan. pu cusku le se du'u

section.para: Probably the most counterintuitive of the Lojban examples is . The ca looks quite odd, as if George were going to the market right now, rather than back when John spoke. But this ca is really a ca with respect to a reference point specified by the outer pu. This behavior is the same as the additive behavior of multiple tenses in the same bridi, as explained in .

nausyntax
tenseoverriding to speaker's current
tensespeaker's current
There is a special cmavo nau (of selma'o CUhE) which can be used to override these rules and get to the speaker's current reference point. (Yes, it sounds like English now.) It is not grammatical to combine nau with any other cmavo in a tense, except by way of a logical or non-logical connection (see ). Here is a convoluted sentence with several nested bridi which uses nau at the lowest level:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .djan. pu cusku le se du'u
… la .alis pu cusku le se du'u
… la .djordj. pu cusku le se du'u

interlinear-gloss.natlang: John said that Alice had said that George had earlier said that Mary is now going to the market.

section.para:
sticky tenseseffect of nau on
naueffect on sticky tenses
The use of nau does not affect sticky tenses.

section.title: Tense relations between sentences
section.para: tense with sumtcitaasymmetry of The sumtcita method, explained in , of asserting a tense relationship between two events suffers from asymmetry. Specifically,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba cu cadzu le bisli
… zu'a le nu le nanmu cu batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: … [left] the event-of the man - bites the dog.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The child walks on the ice to the left of where the man bites the dog.

section.para:
sentencesconnecting with tense
tenseconnecting sentences in with
which specifies an imaginary journey leftward from the man biting the dog to the child walking on the ice, claims only that the child walks on the ice. By the nature of le nu , the man's biting the dog is merely referred to without being claimed. If it seems desirable to claim both, each event can be expressed as a main sentence bridi, with a special form of .i connecting them:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku
… .izu'abo le verba cu cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The man bites the dog. To the left, the child walks on the ice.

section.para: .izu'abo is a compound cmavo: the .i separates the sentences and the zu'a is the tense. The bo is required to prevent the zu'a from gobbling up the following sumti, namely le verba.

tensesumtcita form contrasted with connected sentences
tense connection of sentencescontrasted with sumtcita form
imaginary journeyorigin of in tense-connected sentences
tense connection of sentencesorder of
Note that the bridi in
appear in the reverse order from their appearance in . With .izu'abo (and all other afterthought tense connectives) the sentence specifying the origin of the journey comes first. This is a natural order for sentences, but requires some care when converting between this form and the sumtcita form.
means the same thing as:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku .i zu'a la'edi'u
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man - bites the dog. - [Left] the-referent-of-the-last-sentence

interlinear-gloss.jbo: … le verba cu cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The man bites the dog. Left of what I just mentioned, the child walks on the ice.

section.para:
tense connected sentencesimportance of bo in
If the bo is omitted in
, the meaning changes:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku
… .i zu'a le verba cu - cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The man bites the dog. To the left of the child, something walks on the ice.

section.para: Here the first place of the second sentence is unspecified, because zu'a has absorbed the sumti le verba.

Do not confuse either
or
with the following: separately tensed sentencescontrasted with tense connected sentences
tense connected sentencescontrasted with separately tensed sentences

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku
… .i zu'aku le verba cu cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The man bites the dog. Left of me, the child walks on the ice.

section.para:
In
, the origin point is the speaker, as is usual with zu'aku.
makes the origin point of the tense the event described by the first sentence.

tense connected sentencesforethought mode
Two sentences may also be connected in forethought by a tense relationship. Just like afterthought tense connection, forethought tense connection claims both sentences, and in addition claims that the time or space relationship specified by the tense holds between the events the two sentences describe.

PU selma'ofor forethought tense connection of sentences
imaginary journeyorigin in tense forethought sentence connection
sentencesforethought tense connection of
forethought tense connection of sentencesorder of
The origin sentence is placed first, preceded by a tense plus gi. Another gi is used to separate the sentences:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: pugi mi klama le zarci gi mi klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [past] I go-to the market [,] I go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Before I go to the market, I go to the house.

section.para:
A parallel construction can be used to express a tense relationship between sumti: sumtiforethought tense connection of
imaginary journeyorigin in tense forethought sumti connection
forethought tense connection of sumtiorder of

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama pugi le zarci gi le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to [past] the market [,] the house.

section.para:
Because English does not have any direct way of expressing a tense-like relationship between nouns,
cannot be expressed in English without paraphrasing it either into
or else into I go to the house before the market , which is ambiguous – is the market going?

bridi-tailsforethought tense connection of
imaginary journeyorigin in tense forethought bridi-tail connection
forethought tense connection of bridi-tailsorder of
Finally, a third forethought construction expresses a tense relationship between bridi-tails rather than whole bridi. (The construct known as a bridi-tail is explained fully in
; roughly speaking, it is a selbri, possibly with following sumti.)
is equivalent in meaning to
and
:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pugi klama le zarci gi klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past] go-to the market [,] go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I, before going to the market, go to the house.

section.para:
tense connection of bridi-tailsmeaning of
tense connection of sumtimeaning of
In both
and
, the underlying sentences mi klama le zarci and mi klama le zdani are not claimed; only the relationship in time between them is claimed.

tense afterthought connection formsselma'o allowed
tense forethought connection formsselma'o allowed
tense connectionexpansions of
tense connectionequivalent meanings
Both the forethought and the afterthought forms are appropriate with PU, ZI, FAhA, VA, and ZAhO tenses. In all cases, the equivalent forms are (where X and Y stand for sentences, and TENSE for a tense cmavo):

section.title: Tensed logical connectives
section.para:
tensed logical connectives logical connectivestensed The Lojban tense system interacts with the Lojban logical connective system. That system is a separate topic, explained in and touched on only in summary here. By the rules of the logical connective system,
through
are equivalent in meaning:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .teris. satre le mlatu .ije la .teris. satre le ractu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Terry strokes the cat. And Terry strokes the rabbit.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .teris. satre le mlatu gi'e satre le ractu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Terry strokes the cat and strokes the rabbit.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .teris. satre le mlatu .e le ractu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Terry strokes the cat and the rabbit.

section.para: Suppose we wish to add a tense relationship to the logical connective and ? To say that Terry strokes the cat and later strokes the rabbit, we can combine a logical connective with a tense connective by placing the logical connective first, then the tense, and then the cmavo bo , thus:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .teris. satre le mlatu .ijebabo la .teris. satre le ractu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Terry strokes the cat. And then Terry strokes the rabbit.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .teris. satre le mlatu gi'ebabo satre le ractu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Terry strokes the cat, and then strokes the rabbit.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .teris. satre le mlatu .ebabo le ractu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Terry strokes the cat and then the rabbit.

section.para:
tensed logically connected sumti tensed logically connected bridi-tails tensed logically connected sentences
through
are equivalent in meaning. They are also analogous to
through
respectively. The bo is required for the same reason as in
: to prevent the ba from functioning as a sumtcita for the following sumti (or, in
, from being attached to the following selbri).

tensed logical connectiveswith "tu'e"…"tu'u"
tensed logical connectiveswith "ke"…"ke'e"
In addition to the bo construction of
through
, there is also a form of tensed logical connective with ke … ke'e ( tu'e … tu'u for sentences). The logical connective system makes
through
equivalent in meaning:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli .ije tu'e mi bevri le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack. And ( I carry the dog.

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I carry the sack. And I carry the dog, or I carry the cat, or I carry both.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli gi'eke bevri le gerku gi'a bevri
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack and (carry the dog and/or carry

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I carry the sack, and also carry the dog or carry the cat or carry both.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli .eke le gerku .a le mlatu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack and (the dog or the cat).
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I carry the sack and also the dog or the cat or both.

section.para: Note the uniformity of the Lojban, as contrasted with the variety of ways in which the English provides for the correct grouping. In all cases, the meaning is that I carry the sack in any case, and either the cat or the dog or both.

To express that I carry the sack first (earlier in time), and then the dog or the cat or both simultaneously, I can insert tenses to form
through
:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli .ije ba tu'e mi bevri le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack. And [future] ( I carry the dog.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: … .ija cabo mi bevri le mlatu tu'u
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I carry the sack. And then I will carry the dog or I will carry the cat or I will carry both at once.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli gi'e bake bevri le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack and [future] (carry the dog

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I carry the sack and then will carry the dog or carry the cat or carry both at once.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi bevri le dakli .e bake le gerku
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I carry the sack and [future] (the dog

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I carry the sack, and then the dog or the cat or both at once.

section.para:
tensed logically connected sumtiwith grouping
tensed logically connected bridi-tailswith grouping
tensed logically connected sentenceswith grouping
through
are equivalent in meaning to each other, and correspond to the tenseless
through
respectively.

section.title: Tense negation
section.para:
ZAhO selma'ocontradictory negation of FAhA selma'ocontradictory negation of PU selma'ocontradictory negation of
negationof tenses
tensesnegating
Any bridi which involves tenses of selma'o PU, FAhA, or ZAhO can be contradicted by a -nai suffixed to the tense cmavo. Some examples:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I didn't go to the market.

section.para:
negation of tensesmeaning of
tensescontradictory negation of with "nai"
As a contradictory negation,
implies that the bridi as a whole is false without saying anything about what is true. When the negated tense is a sumtcita, -nai negation indicates that the stated relationship does not hold:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci ca nai
… le nu do klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: … the event-of you go-to the house.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: It is not true that I went to the market at the same time that you went to the house.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku ne'inai le kumfa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man -- bites the dog [within-not] the room.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The man didn't bite the dog inside the room.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi morsi ca'onai le nu mi jmive
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-dead [continuitive-negated] the event-of I live.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: It is false that I am dead during my life.

section.para:
PU selma'onegation with NAhE
NAhE selma'ofor negating PU
tensecontradictory negation contrasted with scalar negation of
tensescalar negation contrasted with contradictory negation of
tensescalar negation of with NAhE
It is also possible to perform scalar negation of whole tense constructs by placing a member of NAhE before them. Unlike contradictory negation, scalar negation asserts a truth: that the bridi is true with some tense other than that specified. The following examples are scalar negation analogues of
to
:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e pu klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go to the market other than in the past.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu batci le gerku to'e ne'i le kumfa
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The man -- bites the dog [opposite-of] [within] the room.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The man bites the dog outside the room.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama le zarci na'e ca le nu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go-to the market [non-] [present] the event-of

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I went to the market at a time other than the time at which you went to the house.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi morsi na'e ca'o le nu mi jmive
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-dead [non-] [continuitive] the event-of I live.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I am dead other than during my life.

section.para:
FAhA selma'onegation with NAhE
An example of scalar negation of FAhA:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba na'e ri'u cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The child walks on the ice other than to my right.

section.para:
ROI selma'oscalar negation of
TAhE selma'oscalar negation of
The use of -nai on cmavo of TAhE and ROI has already been discussed in
; this use is also a scalar negation.

section.title: Actuality, potentiality, capability: CAhA
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

innate capabilitiesexpressing implicitly
potential eventsexpressing implicitly
Lojban bridi without tense markers may not necessarily refer to actual events: they may also refer to capabilities or potential events. For example:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: All ducks swim by floating.

section.para:
actualityLojban contrasted with English in implying
tenseLojban contrasted with English in implying actuality
is a Lojban truth, even though the colloquial English translation is false or at best ambiguous. This is because the tenseless Lojban bridi doesn't necessarily claim that every duck is swimming or floating now or even at a specific time or place. Even if we add a tense marker to
,

interlinear-gloss.natlang: All ducks are now swimming by floating.

section.para:
the resulting
might still be considered a truth, even though the colloquial English seems even more likely to be false. All ducks have the potential of swimming even if they are not exercising that potential at present. To get the full flavor of All ducks are now swimming , we must append a marker from selma'o CAhA to the tense, and say:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: All ducks are now actually swimming by floating.

section.para:
sticky tensesand CAhA
CAhA selma'omaking sticky
CAhA selma'oorder in tense construct
actual eventsexplicitly expressing
A CAhA cmavo is always placed after any other tense cmavo, whether for time or for space. However, a CAhA cmavo comes before ki , so that a CAhA condition can be made sticky.
is false in both Lojban and English, since it claims that the swimming is an actual, present fact, true of every duck that exists, whereas in fact there is at least one duck that is not swimming now.

innate capabilityexpressing explicitly
Furthermore, some ducks are dead (and therefore sink); some ducks have just hatched (and do not know how to swim yet), and some ducks have been eaten by predators (and have ceased to exist as separate objects at all). Nevertheless, all these ducks have the innate capability of swimming – it is part of the nature of duckhood. The cmavo ka'e expresses this notion of innate capability:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: All ducks are innately capable of swimming.

section.para:
innate propertiesextension of from mass to individuals
Under some epistemologies, innate capability can be extended in order to apply the innate properties of a mass to which certain individuals belong to the individuals themselves, even if those individuals are themselves not capable of fulfilling the claim of the bridi. For example:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: John is innately capable of seeing.
John can see.

section.para:
innate propertiesextension to individuals not actually capable
might be true about a human being named John, even though he has been blind since birth, because the ability to see is innately built into his nature as a human being. It is theoretically possible that conditions might occur that would enable John to see (a great medical discovery, for example). On the other hand,

interlinear-gloss.natlang: The book can see.

section.para: is not true in most epistemologies, since the ability to see is not part of the innate nature of a book.

undemonstrated potentialexpressing
Consider once again the newly hatched ducks mentioned earlier. They have the potential of swimming, but have not yet demonstrated that potential. This may be expressed using nu'o , the cmavo of CAhA for undemonstrated potential:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: All infant ducks have an undemonstrated potential for swimming by floating.
Baby ducks can swim but haven't yet.

section.para:
demonstrated potentialexpressing
Contrariwise, if Frank is not blind from birth, then pu'i is appropriate:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: Frank has demonstrated a potential for seeing.
Frank can see and has seen.

section.para:
actualityexpressing in past/future
potentialexpressing in past/future
Note that the glosses given at the beginning of this section for ca'a , nu'o , and pu'i incorporate ca into their meaning, and are really correct for ca ca'a , ca nu'o , and ca pu'i. However, the CAhA cmavo are perfectly meaningful with other tenses than the present:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu ca'a klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I actually went to the store.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .frank. ba nu'o klama le zdani
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Frank could have, but will not have, gone to the store (at some understood moment in the future).

section.para:
tenses with elided CAhAmeaning
As always in Lojban tenses, a missing CAhA can have an indeterminate meaning, or the context can be enough to disambiguate it. Saying

with no CAhA specified can translate the two very different English sentences That is on fire and That is inflammable. The first demands immediate action (usually), whereas the second merely demands caution. The two cases can be disambiguated with:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is on fire.

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is capable of burning.
That is inflammable.

section.para:
observative with elided CAhAconvention
When no indication is given, as in the simple observative

interlinear-gloss.natlang: It burns!

section.para: the prudent Lojbanist will assume the meaning Fire!

section.title: Logical and non-logical connections between tenses
section.para: Like many things in Lojban, tenses may be logically connected; logical connection is explained in more detail in . Some of the terminology in this section will be clear only if you already understand logical connectives.

JA selma'obetween tenses
logically connected tensesexpansion to sentences
tenseslogically connected with JA
logically connected tenseswith JA
The appropriate logical connectives belong to selma'o JA. A logical connective between tenses can always be expanded to one between sentences:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi pu je ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I went and will go to the market.

section.para: means the same as:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I went to the market, and I will go to the market.

section.para:
tensesconnected with negation
Tense connection and tense negation are combined in:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi punai je canai je ba klama le zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I [past-not] and [present-not] and [future] go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I haven't yet gone to the market, but I will in future.

section.para: is far more specific than
which only says that I will go, without claiming anything about my past or present. ba does not imply punai or canai ; to compel that interpretation, either a logical connection or a ZAhO is needed.

connected tensesnegation of compared with negation in connective
Tense negation can often be removed in favor of negation in the logical connective itself. The following examples are equivalent in meaning:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I walk not leftward but rightward.
I walk not leftward but rightward.

section.para:
tensespossible groupings of
tensesforethought logical connections
There are no forethought logical connections between tenses allowed by the grammar, to keep tenses simpler. Nor is there any way to override simple left-grouping of the connectives, the Lojban default.

GAhO selma'obetween tenses
JOI selma'obetween tenses
intervalsexpressing by endpoints with "bi'o"
tensesnon-logical connection of
The non-logical connectives of selma'o JOI, BIhI, and GAhO are also permitted between tenses. One application is to specify intervals not by size, but by their end-points ( bi'o belongs to selma'o BIhI, and connects the end-points of an ordered interval, like English from ... to):

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I breathe from a medium time ago till a long time to come.

section.para: (It is to be hoped that I have a long life ahead of me.)
One additional use of non-logical connectives within tenses is discussed in . Other uses will probably be identified in future.

section.title: Sub-events
section.para: tensesnon-logical connection of for sub-events Another application of non-logical tense connection is to talk about sub-events of events. Consider a six-shooter: a gun which can fire six bullets in succession before reloading. If I fire off the entire magazine twice, I can express the fact in Lojban thus:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: On two occasions, I fire the gun six times.

section.para:
cross productwith tenses
Cartesian productwith tenses
pi'uuse in connecting tenses
It would be confusing, though grammatical, to run the reroi and the xaroi directly together. However, the non-logical connective pi'u expresses a Cartesian product (also known as a cross product) of two sets. In this case, there is a set of two firings each of which is represented by a set of six shots, for twelve shots in all (hence the name product : the product of 2 and 6 is 12). Its use specifies very precisely what occurs.

event contoursstrings of
interval propertiesstrings of
In fact, you can specify strings of interval properties and event contours within a single tense without the use of a logical or non-logical connective cmavo. This allows tenses of the type:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: George continues to start to write.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi reroi ca'o xaroi darxi le damri
interlinear-gloss.natlang: On two occasions, I continue to beat the drum six times.

section.title: Conversion of sumtcita: JAI
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

SE selma'ocompared with JAI and "fai"
conversiondefinition
Conversion is the regular Lojban process of moving around the places of a place structure. The cmavo of selma'o SE serve this purpose, exchanging the first place with one of the others:

jaiused with tense as equivalent of SE in grammar
tense conversionaccessing tense of bridi with "jai"
conversionaccessing tense of bridi with "jai"
It is also possible to bring a place that is specified by a sumtcita (for the purposes of this chapter, a tense sumtcita) to the front, by using jai plus the tense as the grammatical equivalent of SE:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le ratcu cu citka le cirla vi le panka
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The rat - eats the cheese [short-distance] the park.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The rat eats the cheese in the park.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le panka cu jai--vi citka le cirla fai le ratcu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The park - is-the-place-of eating the cheese by the rat.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: The park is where the rat eats the cheese.

section.para:
tense conversionaccessing original first place with "fai"
In
, the construction JAI+tense converts the location sumti into the first place. The previous first place has nowhere to go, since the location sumti is not a numbered place; however, it can be inserted back into the bridi with fai , the indefinite member of selma'o FA.
(The other members of FA are used to mark the first, second, etc. places of a bridi explicitly:

example.jbophrase: fa mi cu klama fe le zarci

section.para: means the same as

example.jbophrase: fe le zarci cu klama fa mi

section.para: as well as the simple
in which the place structure is determined by position.)

LE selma'ousage with selbri with JAI
tense conversionuse in sumti descriptions
Like SE conversion, JAI+tense conversion is especially useful in descriptions with LE selma'o:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi viska le jai--vi citka be le cirla
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I saw the place-of eating - the cheese.

section.para: Here the eater of the cheese is elided, so no fai appears.

tense conversionof temporal tenses
Of course, temporal tenses are also usable with JAI:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi djuno fi le jai ca morsi be fai la .djan.
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I know about the - [present] is-dead - of that-named John.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I know the time of John's death.
I know when John died.

section.title: Tenses versus modals
section.para:
modalscontrasted with tenses in semantics tensescontrasted with modals in semantics modalscompared with tenses in syntax
tensescompared with modals in syntax
Grammatically, every use of tenses seen so far is exactly paralleled by some use of modals as explained in . Modals and tenses alike can be followed by sumti, can appear before the selbri, can be used in pure and mixed connections, can participate in JAI conversions. The parallelism is perfect. However, there is a deep difference in the semantics of tense constructs and modal constructs, grounded in historical differences between the two forms. Originally, modals and tenses were utterly different things in earlier versions of Loglan; only in Lojban have they become grammatically interchangeable. And even now, differences in semantics continue to be maintained.

modalsimportance of 1st sumti place for sumtcita use
The core distinction is that whereas the modal bridi

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi nelci do mu'i le nu do nelci mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I like you with-motivation the event-of you like me.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I like you because you like me.

section.para: places the le nu sumti in the x1 place of the gismu mukti (which underlies the modal mu'i), namely the motivating event, the tensed bridi

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi nelci do ba le nu do nelci mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I like you after the event-of you like me.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I like you after you like me.

section.para:
tensesimportance of 2nd sumti place for sumtcita use
places the le nu sumti in the x2 place of the gismu balvi (which underlies the tense ba), namely the point of reference for the future tense. Paraphrases of
and
, employing the brivla mukti and balvi explicitly, would be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nu do nelci mi cu mukti le nu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The event-of you like me - motivates the event-of

interlinear-gloss.natlang: Your liking me is the motive for my liking you.

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nu mi nelci do cu balvi le nu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The event-of I like you - is-after the event-of

interlinear-gloss.natlang: My liking you follows (in time) your liking me.

section.para:
afterthought sentence connectionmodal contrasted with tense
As a result, the afterthought sentence-connective forms of
and
are, respectively:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi nelci do .imu'ibo do nelci mi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I like you. [That-is]--Because you like me.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do nelci mi .ibabo mi nelci do
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You like me. Afterward, I like you.

section.para:
In
, the order of the two bridi mi nelci do and do nelci mi is the same as in . In
, however, the order is reversed: the origin point do nelci mi physically appears before the future-time event mi nelci do. In both cases, the bridi characterizing the event in the x2 place appears before the bridi characterizing the event in the x1 place of mukti or balvi.

afterthought tense connectioncontrasted with forethought in likeness to modal connection
forethought tense connectioncontrasted with afterthought in likeness to modal connection
forethought connectionsmodal compared with tense in semantics
In forethought connections, however, the asymmetry between modals and tenses is not found. The forethought equivalents of
and
are

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mu'igi do nelci mi gi mi nelci do
interlinear-gloss.gloss: Because you like me , I like you.

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.jbo: bagi do nelci mi gi mi nelci do
interlinear-gloss.gloss: After you like me , I like you.

section.para: respectively.

modal sentence connectiontable of equivalent schemata
The following modal sentence schemata (where X and Y represent sentences) all have the same meaning:

tense sentence connectiontable of equivalent schemata
whereas the following tensed sentence schemata also have the same meaning:

neglecting the question of what is claimed. In the modal sentence schemata, the modal tag is always followed by Y, the sentence representing the event in the x1 place of the gismu that underlies the BAI. In the tensed sentences, no such simple rule exists.

section.title: Tense questions: cu'e
section.para: The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

mafor tense questions
tense questions with "ma" tense questionsmethods of asking
There are two main ways to ask questions about tense. The main English tense question words are When? and Where?. These may be paraphrased respectively as At what time? and At what place? In these forms, their Lojban equivalents simply involve a tense plus ma , the Lojban sumti question:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do klama le zdani ca ma
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You go-to the house at what-time?
interlinear-gloss.natlang: When do you go to the house?

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le verba vi ma pu cadzu le bisli
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The child at/near what-place - walked-on the ice?
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Where did the child walk on the ice?

section.para:
modal-or-tense questionwith "cu'e"
tense-or-modal questionswith "cu'e"
There is also a non-specific tense and modal question, cu'e , belonging to selma'o CUhE. This can be used wherever a tense or modal construct can be used.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le nanmu cu'e batci le gerku
interlinear-gloss.natlang: When/Where/How does the man bite the dog?

section.para:
answersto tense-or-modal questions
Possible answers to
might be:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: Some ways from here.
A long time ago.
On the moon.
He hasn't yet done so.

section.para: or even the modal reply (from selma'o BAI; see ):

modal-or-tense questionspre-specifying some information
tense-or-modal questionspre-specifying some information
cu'ecombining with other tense cmavo
The only way to combine cu'e with other tense cmavo is through logical connection, which makes a question that pre-specifies some information:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do puzi je cu'e sombo le gurni
interlinear-gloss.natlang: You sowed the grain a little while ago; when else do you sow it?

section.para: Additionally, the logical connective itself can be replaced by a question word: tense questionsby using logical connective question

interlinear-gloss.natlang: Was Arthur a king or will he be?

section.para:
Answers to
would be logical connectives such as je , meaning both , naje meaning the latter , or jenai meaning the former.

section.title: Explicit magnitudes
section.para: It is a limitation of the VA and ZI system of specifying magnitudes that they can only prescribe vague magnitudes: small, medium, or large. In order to express both an origin point and an exact distance, the Lojban construction called a termset is employed. (Termsets are explained further in and .) It is grammatical for a termset to be placed after a tense or modal tag rather than a sumti, which allows both the origin of the imaginary journey and its distance to be specified. Here is an example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: … la'u lo mitre be li mu [nu'u]
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Frank is standing five meters to the left of George.

section.para: Here the termset extends from the nu'i to the implicit nu'u at the end of the sentence, and includes the terms la .djordj. , which is the unmarked origin point, and the tagged sumti lo mitre be li mu , which the cmavo la'u (of selma'o BAI, and meaning with quantity ; see ) marks as a quantity. Both terms are governed by the tag zu'a

It is not necessary to have both an origin point and an explicit magnitude: a termset may have only a single term in it. A less precise version of
is:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: Frank stands five meters to the left.

section.title: Finally (an exercise for the much-tried reader)

example.jbophrase: .a'o do pu seju ba roroi ca'o fe'e su'oroi jimpe fi le lojbo temci selsku ciste

section.title: Summary of tense selma'o tense selma'osummary of

listitem.para: temporal direction
temporal distance
temporal interval
objective quantified tense flag
subjective quantified tense
event contours
see
spatial direction
see
spatial distance
spatial interval
spatial dimensionality
spatial interval modifier flag
etc.
spatial movement flag
see
set or reset sticky tense
tense question, reference point

cmavo-entry.description: asks for a tense or aspect

listitem.para: tense conversion
etc.

section.title: List of spatial directions and direction-like relations
section.para:
spatial directionslist of
mo'i bu'u ca'u ti'a zu'a ri'u ga'u ni'a ne'i ru'u pa'o ne'a te'e re'o fa'a to'o zo'i ze'o zo'a be'a ne'u du'a vu'a fa'a to'o zo'i ze'o zo'i ze'o fa'a to'o The following list of FAhA cmavo gives rough English glosses for the cmavo, first when used without mo'i to express a direction, and then when used with mo'i to express movement in the direction. When possible, the gismu from which the cmavo is derived is also listed.

cmavo-entry.description: coincident with ; at the same place as

section.para:
ze'ospecial note on direction orientation
zo'ispecial note on direction orientation
to'ospecial note on direction orientation
fa'aspecial note on direction orientation
Special note on fa'a , to'o , zo'i , and ze'o :
zo'i and ze'o refer to direction towards or away from the speaker's location, or whatever the origin is.
fa'a and to'o refer to direction towards or away from some other point.

chapter.title: Events, qualities, quantities, and other vague words: on Lojban abstraction

section.title: The syntax of abstraction
section.para: The purpose of the feature of Lojban known as abstraction is to provide a means for taking whole bridi and packaging them up, as it were, into simple selbri. Syntactically, abstractions are very simple and uniform; semantically, they are rich and complex, with few features in common between one variety of abstraction and another. We will begin by discussing syntax without regard to semantics; as a result, the notion of abstraction may seem unmotivated at first. Bear with this difficulty until .

An abstraction selbri is formed by taking a full bridi and preceding it by any cmavo of selma'o NU. There are twelve such cmavo; they are known as abstractors. The bridi is closed by the elidable terminator kei , of selma'o KEI. Thus, to change the bridi
into an abstraction using nu , one of the members of selma'o NU, we change it into

KEI selma'oeliding
observativesand abstractions
The bridi may be a simple selbri, or it may have associated sumti, as here. It is important to beware of eliding kei improperly, as many of the common uses of abstraction selbri involve following them with words that would appear to be part of the abstraction if kei had been elided.

(Technically, kei is never necessary, because the elidable terminator vau that closes every bridi can substitute for it; however, kei is specific to abstractions, and using it is almost always clearer.)

tanruand abstractions
abstractionsgrammatical uses
The grammatical uses of an abstraction selbri are exactly the same as those of a simple brivla. In particular, abstraction selbri may be used as observatives, as in
, or used in tanru:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .djan. -- cu nu sonci kei -- djica
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That-named John is-an - (event-of being-a-soldier ) type-of desirer.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: John wants to be a soldier.

section.para:
descriptionsand abstractions
Abstraction selbri may also be used in descriptions, preceded by le (or any other member of selma'o LE):

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .djan. cu djica le nu sonci [kei]
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That-named John -- desires the event-of being-a-soldier.

section.para: We will most often use descriptions containing abstraction either at the end of a bridi, or just before the main selbri with its cu ; in either of these circumstances, kei can normally be elided.

abstractionsplace structure
The place structure of an abstraction selbri depends on the particular abstractor, and will be explained individually in the following sections.

Note: In glosses of bridi within abstractions, the grammatical form used in the English changes. Thus, in the gloss of
we see my going-to the store rather than I go-to the store ; likewise, in the glosses of
and
we see being-a-soldier rather than is-a-soldier. This procedure reflects the desire for more understandable glosses, and does not indicate any change in the Lojban form. A bridi is a bridi, and undergoes no change when it is used as part of an abstraction selbri.

section.title: Event abstraction
section.para: abstractionsevent event abstractions The following cmavo is discussed in this section:

le nudefinition
nudefinition
common abstractor The examples in
made use of nu as the abstractor, and it is certainly the most common abstractor in Lojban text. Its purpose is to capture the event or state of the bridi considered as a whole. Do not confuse the le description built on a nu abstraction with ordinary descriptions based on le alone. The following sumti are quite distinct:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: the comer, that which comes
the destination
the origin
the route
the means of transportation
the event of someone coming to somewhere from somewhere by some route using some means

section.para:
through
are descriptions that isolate the five individual sumti places of the selbri klama.
describes something associated with the bridi as a whole: the event of it.

eventsduration
In Lojban, the term event is divorced from its ordinary English sense of something that happens over a short period of time. The description:
is an event which lasts for the whole of my life (under normal circumstances). On the other hand,

interlinear-gloss.gloss: the event-of that-named John kissing that-named Jane

section.para: normal circumstances is relatively brief by comparison (again, under normal circumstances).

abstractionssumti ellipsis in
We can see from
through
that ellipsis of sumti is valid in the bridi of abstraction selbri, just as in the main bridi of a sentence. Any sumti may be ellipsized if the listener will be able to figure out from context what the proper value of it is, or else to recognize that the proper value is unimportant. It is extremely common for nu abstractions in descriptions to have the x1 place ellipsized:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I like swimming.

section.para: is elliptical, and most probably means:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi nelci le nu mi limna
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I like the event-of I swim.

section.para:
In the proper context, of course,
could refer to the event of somebody else swimming. Its English equivalent, I like swimming , can't be interpreted as I like Frank's swimming ; this is a fundamental distinction between English and Lojban. In Lojban, an omitted sumti can mean whatever the context indicates that it should mean.

abstractionsimplicit in sumti
Note that the lack of an explicit NU cmavo in a sumti can sometimes hide an implicit abstraction. In the context of
, the appearance of le se nelci ( that which is liked) is in effect an abstraction:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: The thing which I like happens often.

section.para: which in this context means
Event descriptions with le nu are commonly used to fill the under conditions... places, among others, of gismu and lujvo place structures:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: Lojban is easy for me when I study.

section.para: (The when of the English would also be appropriate for a construction involving a Lojban tense, but the Lojban sentence says more than that the studying is concurrent with the ease.)

nuplace structure
eventsplace structure
The place structure of a nu abstraction selbri is simply:

definition.content: x1 is an event of (the bridi)

section.title: Types of event abstractions
section.para: event abstractionstypes The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

Event abstractions with nu suffice to express all kinds of events, whether long, short, unique, repetitive, or whatever. Lojban also has more finely discriminating machinery for talking about events, however. There are four other abstractors of selma'o NU for talking about four specific types of events, or four ways of looking at the same event.

achievement abstractionsdefinition
point-event abstractionsdefinition
abstractionsachievement
abstractionspoint-event
triumph point-event abstractor An event considered as a point in time is called a point-event , or sometimes an achievement. (This latter word should be divorced, in this context, from all connotations of success or triumph.) A point-event can be extended in duration, but it is still a point-event if it is thought of as unitary, having no internal structure. The abstractor mu'e means point-event-of :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le mu'e la .djan. catra la .djim. cu zekri
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The point-event-of (that-named John kills that-named Jim) -- is-a-crime.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: John's killing Jim (considered as a point in time) is a crime.

section.para:
abstractionsprocess
process abstractionsdefinition
process abstractor killing Jim An event considered as extended in time, and structured with a beginning, a middle containing one or more stages, and an end, is called a process. The abstractor pu'u means process-of :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ca'o le pu'u le latmo balje'a cu porpi kei
interlinear-gloss.gloss: [continuitive] the process-of( the Latin great-state - breaking-up )

interlinear-gloss.natlang: During the fall of the Roman Empire, many Emperors were killed.

section.para:
abstractionsactivity
activity abstractionsdefinition
activity abstractor Roman Empire An event considered as extended in time and cyclic or repetitive is called an activity. The abstractor zu'o means activity-of :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi tatpi ri'a le zu'o mi plipe
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-tired because-of the activity-of (I jump).
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I am tired because I jump.

section.para:
abstractionsstate
state abstractionsdefinition
state abstractor An event considered as something that is either happening or not happening, with sharp boundaries, is called a state. The abstractor za'i means state-of :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: le za'i mi jmive cu ckape do
interlinear-gloss.natlang: My being alive is dangerous to you.

section.para:
event typesdescribed
The abstractors in
through
could all have been replaced by nu , with some loss of precision. Note that Lojban allows every sort of event to be viewed in any of these four ways:

listitem.para:
state eventdescribed
the state of running begins when the runner starts and ends when the runner stops;

activity eventdescribed
the activity of running consists of the cycle lift leg, step forward, drop leg, lift other leg... (each such cycle is a process, but the activity consists in the repetition of the cycle);

process eventdescribed
slowdown steady speed the process of running puts emphasis on the initial sprint, the steady speed, and the final slowdown;

achievement eventdescribed
Athens indivisible marathon Pheidippides the achievement of running is most alien to English, but sees the event of running as a single indivisible thing, like Pheidippides' run from Marathon to Athens (the original marathon).

section.para: Further information on types of events can be found in .
The four event type abstractors have the following place structures:
section.definition:
mu'e : x1 is a point event of (the bridi) achievement abstractionplace structure
point-event abstractionplace structure
mu'eplace structure

pu'u : x1 is a process of (the bridi) with stages x2 process abstractionplace structure
pu'uplace structure

za'i : x1 is a continuous state of (the bridi) being true state abstractionplace structure
za'iplace structure

zu'o : x1 is an activity of (the bridi) consisting of repeated actions x2 activity abstractionplace structure
zu'oplace structure

section.title: Property abstractions
section.para: The following cmavo are discussed in this section:

The things described by le nu descriptions (or, to put it another way, the things of which nu selbri may correctly be predicated) are only moderately abstract. They are still closely tied to happenings in space and time. Properties, however, are much more ethereal. What is the property of being blue , or the property of being a go-er ? They are what logicians call intensions. If John has a heart, then the property of having a heart is an abstract object which, when applied to John, is true. In fact,

interlinear-gloss.natlang: John has a heart.

section.para: has the same truth conditions as

interlinear-gloss.natlang: John has the property of having a heart.

section.para:
havingof properties
(The English word have frequently appears in any discussion of Lojban properties: things are said to have properties, but this is not the same sense of have as in I have money , which is possession.)
Property descriptions, like event descriptions, are often wanted to fill places in brivla place structures:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do cnino mi le ka xunre [kei]
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You are-new to-me in-the-quality-of-the property-of being-red.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: You are new to me in redness.

section.para: -ity -ness (The English suffix -ness often signals a property abstraction, as does the suffix -ity.)

beachexample
sunburnexample
It would be suitable to use
to someone who has returned from the beach with a sunburn.

property abstractionsspecifying determining place by sumti ellipsis
property abstractionssumti ellipsis in
There are several different properties that can be extracted from a bridi, depending on which place of the bridi is understood as being specified externally. Thus:
is quite different from

In particular, sentences like
and
are quite different in meaning:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I love John more than I love George.
John loves me more than George loves me.

section.para:
property abstractionsspecifying determining place with "ce'u"
The X used in the glosses of
through
